channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: $4 Billion of New Bitcoin ETFs Change Hands in First Trading Day
item.description: The products, known as exchange-traded funds, were approved by federal regulators this week, a watershed moment for the crypto industry.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:description: Eleven exchange-traded funds tied to Bitcoin started trading on Wall Street on Thursday, a day after federal regulators authorized them.

item.title: AI and Education: Will Chatbots Soon Tutor Your Children?
item.description: New A.I. tools could enable a Silicon Valley dream: bots that customize learning for pupils. Prior attempts have not lived up to the hype.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sal Khan, the chief executive of Khan Academy, predicted last year that A.I. tutoring bots would soon revolutionize education. Big Tech executives have similar visions.

item.title: U.S. Criminally Charges EBay in Cyberstalking Case
item.description: The case involves eBay employees trying to intimidate a Massachusetts couple who write and produce an e-commerce newsletter. The company will pay a criminal penalty of $3 million.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:description: The Justice Department charged eBay on Thursday with stalking, witness tampering and obstruction of justice, stemming from actions taken by the company in 2019 to undermine and silence David and Ina Steiner.

item.title: Discord Cuts 17% of Workers in Latest Tech Layoffs
item.description: In an internal memo, Discord said it had grown five times its size since 2020.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Discord’s layoffs came amid a string of cuts in the tech industry.

item.title: Why Casey Left Substack, Elon Musk and Drugs, and an A.I. Antibiotic Discovery
item.description: It’s a drug episode.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Pat McCusker
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Image: AnthonyRosenberg, via Getty Images

item.title: Hertz Sells 20,000 Electric Cars After Being Burned by Tesla’s Price Cuts
item.description: The rental car company blamed the sharp drop in the value of electric vehicles and higher repair costs for its decision to sell 20,000 cars.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Tesla vehicles make up the largest share of Hertz’s electric fleet, but they plunged in value after the carmaker cut prices by nearly one-third in 2023.

item.title: Federal Regulator Questions Carmakers About Unwanted Tracking via Their Apps
item.description: The Federal Communications Commission is concerned about abusive partners using connected car apps to harass and track their victims.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.media:description: The Federal Communications Commission sent letters to nine of the largest automakers, asking for more information about their connected car apps and whether the companies had processes in place to assist abuse victims.

item.title: No, Taylor Swift no está vendiendo ollas Le Creuset
item.description: El supuesto patrocinio de Swift a los productos de la empresa, que ha aparecido en anuncios publicados en Facebook y otros medios, es falso.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Yiwen Lu
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet para The New York Times
item.media:description: Hola, soy yo. Yo no soy el problema.

item.title: Google Cuts Hundreds of Jobs in Engineering and Other Divisions
item.description: The company, which has been working to trim expenses, laid off employees who worked on core engineering, the Google Assistant product and hardware such as the Pixel phone.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: Google had 182,000 employees as of Sept. 30.

item.title: SEC Approves New Bitcoin ETFs, in Boon for Crypto Industry
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized financial firms to offer a Bitcoin investment product that some hope will accelerate adoption of the technology.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington offices of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which approved 11 applications to offer exchange-traded funds tied to Bitcoin.

item.title: Amazon Cuts Hundreds of Jobs at Studios and Twitch
item.description: The layoffs add to a growing number of cuts in the tech industry this past year.
item.dc:creator: Yiwen Lu
item.media:description: Twitch, a video streaming platform, will cut just over 500 roles, or 35 percent of its work force.

item.title: OpenAI Unveils App Store for Customized Versions of ChatGPT
item.description: People who subscribe to OpenAI’s ChatGPT Plus service will be able to browse the new store for tailored chatbots that perform different tasks.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: People who spend $20 a month for a subscription to OpenAI’s ChatGPT Plus service can browse the new GPT Store for custom chatbots that provide a wide array of services.

item.title: The Best and Worst of Tech: Smartphones, Self-Driving Cars, More
item.description: The best tech, from universal power charging to foldable phones, solved practical problems. But the worst tech, including self-driving cars and cryptocurrency, put us in harm’s way.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China
item.description: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise, Cade Metz and David McCabe
item.media:description: A screen outside a Beijing shopping mall showed news footage of Bill Gates, Microsoft’s co-founder, meeting President Xi Jinping in June.

item.title: The Next Front in the U.S.-China Battle Over Chips
item.description: A U.S.-born chip technology called RISC-V has become critical to China’s ambitions. Washington is debating whether and how to limit the technology.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Ana Swanson

item.title: Editor of The Los Angeles Times Steps Down
item.description: Kevin Merida, who took over the job in 2021, said in an internal note that his last day would be on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Francine Orr/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Kevin Merida, executive editor of The Los Angeles Times.

item.title: A.I. Giant Tied to China Under Scrutiny
item.description: A congressional committee made the demand of the Commerce Department after The Times reported on concerns among U.S. intelligence officials over the Emirati company, G42.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Mark Mazzetti and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed, center, the national security adviser of the Emirates, oversees the artificial intelligence giant G42.

item.title: No, That’s Not Taylor Swift Peddling Le Creuset Cookware
item.description: The singer did not promote a giveaway of the popular cookware, but an artificially generated version of her voice suggested otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Yiwen Lu
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: It’s me, hi, I’m not the problem.

item.title: The New Space Race Is Causing New Pollution Problems
item.description: Earth’s stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: How Astronomers Are Saving Astronomy From Satellites — For Now
item.description: Even the most powerful telescopes are in peril as orbits above Earth fill with thousands of new satellites. But scientists aren’t ready to give up the night sky.
item.dc:creator: Lyndie Chiou

item.title: OpenAI Says New York Times Lawsuit Against It Is ‘Without Merit’
item.description: The artificial intelligence start-up said that it collaborated with news organizations and that The Times, which accused it of copyright infringement, was not telling the full story.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: OpenAI said in a blog post that a New York Times lawsuit accusing it of copyright infringement did not tell the full story of how OpenAI and its technologies, like the ChatGPT chatbot, operated.

item.title: Unity Software to Cut 25% of Its Work Force
item.description: The cuts follow a tough year in which the tech industry laid off tens of thousands of workers.
item.dc:creator: Yiwen Lu
item.media:description: The software from Unity, based in San Francisco, powers the video games of developers.

item.title: Moon Lander Malfunctions After Launch, Raising Questions for NASA
item.description: After a flawless launch to orbit, the privately built robotic Peregrine lander is unlikely to reach the lunar surface because of a failure in its propulsion system.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Astrobotic Peregrine lunar lander during preparations for launch in Florida in November.

item.title: TikTok Quietly Curtails Data Tool Used by Critics
item.description: People and groups had harnessed the tool to scrutinize content on the site related to the Israel-Hamas war and other topics.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:description: TikTok’s Creative Center is meant to help advertisers track popular hashtags on the site.

item.title: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’
item.description: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: Help! An Employee of Budget Kept My Phone and I Can Prove It.
item.description: After misplacing his iPhone while returning a rental car, a traveler tracked down the device and presented strong evidence to the agency that a worker took it — to no avail.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel

item.title: Vulcan Rocket Aces Its First Launch
item.description: Despite problems with one of its payloads, the new launcher’s flight was flawless, showing the potential of several vehicles that could chip away at SpaceX’s dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: United Launch Alliance’s (ULA) Vulcan Centaur, lifting off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on Monday.

item.title: Dark Corners of the Web Offer a Glimpse at A.I.’s Nefarious Future
item.description: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: Switching to a Flip Phone Helped Me Cut Down on My Smartphone Addiction
item.description: Was it inconvenient? Yes. Did T9 texting drive me crazy? Definitely. Was it worth doing? Absolutely.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Plamen Petkov for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Moves Closer to Filing Sweeping Antitrust Case Against Apple
item.description: Justice Department officials are in the late stages of investigating the iPhone maker, focusing on how Apple has used its other products and services to defend against threats to its core business.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department is focused on how Apple has used its control over the iPhone’s software and hardware to make its devices and services work better together.
